user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_QueuePut:
```c
int32 OS_QueuePut(osal_id_t queue_id, const void *data, size_t size, uint32 flags)
{
    OS_object_token_t           token;
    int32                       return_code;
    OS_queue_internal_record_t *queue;

    /* Check Parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(data);
    OS_CHECK_SIZE(size);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_NONE, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, queue_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        queue = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_queue_table, token);

        if (size > queue->max_size)
        {
            /*
            ** The buffer that the user is passing in is too large
            */
            return_code = OS_QUEUE_INVALID_SIZE;
        }
        else
        {
            return_code = OS_QueuePut_Impl(&token, data, size, flags);
        }
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_QueuePut:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
#define OS_CHECK_SIZE(val) ARGCHECK((val)>0&&(val)<(UINT32_MAX/2),OS_ERR_INVALID_SIZE)
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_queue_internal_record_t OS_queue_table[LOCAL_NUM_OBJECTS]
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef struct
{
    char              queue_name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    size_t            max_size;
    osal_blockcount_t max_depth;
} OS_queue_internal_record_t
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
int32 OS_QueuePut_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, const void *data, size_t size, uint32 flags)
{
    int32                            return_code;
    int                              result;
    struct timespec                  ts;
    OS_impl_queue_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_queue_table, *token);

    /*
     * NOTE - using a zero timeout here for the same reason that QueueGet does ---
     * checking the attributes and doing the actual send is non-atomic, and if
     * two threads call QueuePut() at the same time on a nearly-full queue,
     * one could block.
     */
    memset(&ts, 0, sizeof(ts));

    /* send message */
    do
    {
        result = mq_timedsend(impl->id, data, size, 1, &ts);
    } while (result == -1 && errno == EINTR);

    if (result == 0)
    {
        return_code = OS_SUCCESS;
    }
    else if (errno == ETIMEDOUT)
    {
        return_code = OS_QUEUE_FULL;
    }
    else
    {
        /* Something else went wrong */
        return_code = OS_ERROR;
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
#define OS_QUEUE_INVALID_SIZE (-11)
...
typedef int32_t   int32
...
typedef uint32_t  uint32
...
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I examined the provided code and related definitions for occurrences of compiler-specific language extensions. No suspicious fragments were found. Specifically:

- There are no uses of known compiler extensions such as __attribute__, __asm__/asm, __builtin_*, typeof, statement expressions ({ ...; }) used as an expression, nested functions, inline assembler, nonstandard storage-class specifiers, or other documented GCC/Clang/MSVC language extensions.
- The macros (OS_CHECK_POINTER, OS_CHECK_SIZE, OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET, etc.) are ordinary preprocessor macros; their use involves standard address-of and array indexing operators, not an extension.
- Typedefs using fixed-width integer types (int32_t, uint32_t) are from the standard <stdint.h>, not a compiler extension. The custom typedef names (int32, uint32, osal_id_t) are standard typedef usage.
- Use of POSIX APIs/structures (mq_timedsend, struct timespec, errno) are library/OS interfaces, not language/compiler extensions addressed by MISRA C Rule 1.2.
- No compiler-specific pragmas or nonstandard token concatenation, nor any compiler-specific keyword usage was present.

Therefore there are no code fragments in the supplied code that use language compiler extensions (as explicitly documented extensions) that would need investigation under MISRA C:2023 Rule 1.2.
